qbaZ1cUqthJX05CT3MbnpA.text: I was pleasantly surprised that at 7:30pm on a Friday we were able to walk in and be seated.  OK, it was downstairs at the bar, but that is usually my favorite place.  I loved the decor--it was just casual and yet elegant.  I've been to Ceviche and one of my complaints is how noisy it is.  But it was not at all noisy.We had very attentive service which also made me quite happy.We enjoyed tiradito, skewers and a salad and thought they were all tasty.  The salad was a bit disappointing (is there really feta cheese in Peru--I'd imagine it would be queso fresco--it was just a bit out of place and not authentic).  While the food was really good I wouldn't say it was mind-blowing.  The donuts for dessert were quite a treat, although the portion was massive which seemed out of place with the small plates theme.Definitely a place to pop into for a good meal--I'd recommend it.  Good food, good atmosphere.

AjaPAB1UN3VeLdd6ubJxMw.text: Really pleasant experience with sumptuous food and exceptional service. Our server Alexandra was phenomenal with her recommendations. Of course the Ceviché delicious. Really enjoyed the Tacu Tacu Quechua that was recommend by Alexandra was really special.

photos.caption: Photo of Andina - London, United Kingdom. The bar underground.

ROHClyz0VKuSCMMZbIOiHA.text: I came here for my cousin's birthday. The food was delicious! A bit spicy maybe and with loads of red onions, but I have no clue how's the Peruvian cuisine so I assume it is part of the experience! Staff very friendly, we shared a table with other customers which added to the nice casual experience. I didn't put 5 stars just because of the price, but honestly a lot of work has been put into the execution (see pictures).

kz9AZC6exjf1TQof7bhaCQ.text: All the rage?...not so sure why. Expensive for Tapas in my opinion. Good food. Good service. Good cocktails.

6A_g6vbxgGR_zb58yq6BVg.text: Aqui Se Cocina Con Cariño.This is the motto. So let's see if they put enough care in the food or it's just a nice spanish sentence.Eat there on a thursday, 4 people, no booking. The place is crowded (this should be a good sign, but in Shoreditch well... even the off-license stores are crowded in the evening!), but they manage to let us sit in a shared table. Oh yes! I like shared tables, it allows me to look at more plates and have a nice chat! Unfortunately our table sharers are french.... nothing against the country but damn you are snob! anyway..Basically the menu is built over a tapas-alike concept: there are no appetizers or main courses, just small dishes to be shared among everybody. The idea is nice, but I felt a bit in a "aperitivo" time rather than a proper dinner.Round of cocktails (pisco sour as recommended by.. well by everybody in the restaurant), good but not delicious, and then we are ready to receive our plates!In general, we have peruvian cuisine put in a contemporary world: that means for example that we have ceviche but its taste is far smoother than what I tasted in Peru, with less lime and more overall less spicy. That's my main critique: there's nothing hot here! how can you have a peruvian menu with no hotness? spice that dish madame! ah and by the way no lomo saltado... why one of the most famous peruvian dishes is out of the menu? Mysteries...On a tasting level, the raw fish is definitely suggested, every single dish we tried was good, the only issue missing was spices! everything was just a bit too blend... pity! Recommended: the skewers. Now, I usually avoid skewers as they are usually roasted in advance and then re heated, which makes them lose juicies, but here they did a very good job, the meat is moist and the sauces are delicious, not to be missed!Take a minute to choose your wine: I may be biased, but I love south american wines: gimme peruvian or chilean or argentinian wines and maurizio will be a happy guy! and here, as expected , we have a very nice selection of peruvian wines: personally I usually go for white wines in sharing settings, especially in places with lots of fishes and only white meat (mainly chicken). For my personal taste the choice was for the Torrontes, argentinian, which is the only south american grape in the menu, but everything is worthing the money (I could also recommend adobe or gran hacienda, nice drinks!).In conclusion, it's a good place, but in the end you are feeling something is missing, as everything seems just an appetizer! and I really hope thery are gonna kick some spices in the next future, this is something really missing in a south american restaurant!

_0l4I0oh-icYgkHqzzS99g.text: Not very impressed by this place. It's way too pricy for what you get and the set up is quite strange. My friend and I were sitting at the table literally next to some other couple which felt like we were having a family dinner with strangers.The food was ok, but nothing special. Don't think I'm gonna come back there.Plus it's a Peruvian place without Inca cola! :(

GfuqDIESsxBOhVOiyWffnw.text: How funny! Andina made the weekly Yelp the night I made my first Trip. Coinciding with the release of Paddington the movie, I, escaping all the way from the deepest dark depths of South London, travelled on the Marmalade Line all the way to Shoreditch for Dinner, for recipes all the way from the Depths of Peru. The warm and cozy climate inside was a welcoming escape from the cold night air and inside, almost tropical and ever so welcoming to our ever expanding food party. I've oft walked past seeing brunchers stabbing at poached eggs with spears of asparagus, quinoa tumbling about smoked trout, that's what I'm about, but dinner was a rather limited unceremonious affair. Clumsy service came in batches, although I was excited by the array of little plates; Lúcuma paté, native to Andean Peru, a kind of avaocadoey textured but sweet onion-pumpkin tasting paste was a cloying but an interesting paste cleaned up by the Black Kingfish & Fig Tiradito: Farmed and sustainable (slivers of) kingfish, with (an eighth of a piece of some very small non) seasonal British figs and (a few sprinkles of) pomegranate (pips), (however I couldn't taste the exquisite tropical tanginess I was expecting from the) yuzu tiger's milk, but it was 'ceviched' as Andina's big sister knows how nevertheless. The Beef Anticucho skewers, were stamp sized pieces of meat. I'd wanted a huge piece of beating heart and these mere dry morsels did not meet my hungry expectations.  The Causa Misti was a half a spear of green asparagus (may I add, cut in to two) with (a few quarters of) heirloom tomatoes (Yes, so really 1 and a half unripe green cherry tomatoes), with (a sliver of) avocado, (a quenelle of) cold potato mash and (I don't know what) omega 3 boosting Sacha Inchi oil boosted, but it wasn't my confidence in knowing I'd not need a bear sized Marmalade sandwich at home. Andina, named after a strong pioneering woman, had probably had a hearty Peruvian breakfast to start the day, but Peru-sing the menu, it looks more of morning place rather than a place to wind up or down for dinner, despite the Pisco Sours being first class fluffy.Well, you could always start the day with an egg (white based cocktail) here.

Uoc-vqAqBmxrUINoYbAevg.text: We checked out this newly opened Peruvian restaurant in Shoreditch area and were happy to have gone. The restaurant is actually huge as the have lower level dinning area in addition to the main room. They also have and their so called music room which looks ideal for big parties. I personally like the decor of the restaurant, it is modern/minimalist yet homely and clearly Peruvian. I enjoy that they have a juice bar in addition to the full bar. I also like that despite the kitchen being in the main room we left without smelling like food. My only gripe is about the cold draught that enters each time the huge and talll main door opens eapecially in winter time. As for our food, I had the Chicharrones. I love it a lot I wish they have it in bigger serving portion. I love the combination of chillis, onion and pork in a mini clay bowl. My husband on the other hand had the Chupe, which was a stew with potatoes, corn quinoa and shrimp and small chunks of eggs on a chili sauce. Even though it was meant for my husband, I think I ate half of it because it was just that good (lots of love for the husband for letting me share his food). It was a perfect blend of all the ingredients without one over powering the other especially the chilli. In addition, my husband also had the Yucca which is fried cassava with herb dip on the side. My husband liked and enjoyed it and I say it was good but not my favorite. As for my main dish, I had the Lomo which is a rib eye cut steak with broad beans on the side and lucuma pure. The meat was really tender and well marinated and the lucuma was creamy and sweet with a hint of uniques spices and herbs blended in. Overall, the service here was attentive and friendly, the food is unique yet fantastic, the decor is simple but exudes calmness. My husband enjoyed ourselves here and highly recommend it to all. Its wonderful seeing  excellent restaurants like this one in our side of London.

XoFZutHiCcXvVvh8Tj8PaQ.text: Peruvian food at its best. Definitely better than other Peruvian restaurants in town, this place shows both style, attitude, and a delicate menu, boasting daring flavour combinations.The room downstairs is twice as big as the ground floor, so don't be put off if the place looks crowded !

LtdMKruPtC0B6qhtil5fBw.text: Ah I have a weakness for ceviche. Fresh, sharp, tangy, it's incredible.So it was a natural choice for me to want to eat at Andina. 8 of us came for the dinner. I love how young, hip and friendly the staff are, however interminably slow they were at bringing the bill.Andina is not cheap, these tapas style places can really add up. Throw in a few Pisco punches and you are looking at minimum £40 each. I had the Ceviche Andina, tamalitos and chicken causa. The ceviche was spicy and fantastic. The tamalito was essentially quinoa with feta, not a revelation. The causa was surprisingly light and tasty. Highlights were the chicken tamarind I tasted. Definitely order this. And of course, the fried cassava is a must. But do not leave without ordering the dulce de leche pastries with ice cream. Holy shit, Batman, they are amazing.

W8MYWJQufcKxhdgkHhu1Jw.text: Long wait but really worth it. My friends and I had a pisco cocktail while waiting. I really liked the atmosphere of the back room with the communal tables. The plantain banana fritters were so good, we had two of them

3pPzx7qP_L2KSFqGM-mdSQ.text: Andina is another 'small plates' restaurant but Peruvian...The atmosphere inside is great. Nice relaxed vibe but buzzy and feels like a well run place. We were shown to our table right away and the service was really efficient, New York style on the ball which we could do with more of. Another plus is that there was no mention of time slot for the table. This is the way it should be.The ceviche classico was good and fresh tasting but really mouth puckering sour. I'm no expert in ceviche but imagined a more balanced flavour profile. Chicken and avacado causa was OK, a bit bland, one dimensional. Skewers of lamb and chicken thighs with special sauces were also reasonable. I did enjoy the casava chips with herb and nut dipping sauce. Big hot wodges of chewy casava with a pleasing sauce. Food came out quickly and empty plates efficiently cleared up.So good overall, not amazing and a bit expensive as is usually the case with small plates (eg £9 for two small lamb skewers) so the dishes need to stand out more than they did for the price.

2qeuAuHku2XeeJaHeBzy0g.text: had a great brunch experience. fantastic looking, flavorful food, lovingly prepared and served. Choclo Corn cake was absolutely delicious, filling but not heavy, with a generous chunk of avocado, fresh and tasty Peruvian salsa with thinly sliced onions, and the best poached egg i've ever had on the side.it was a windy afternoon, and Andina was busy, so i sat at the bar, enjoyed a good cup of hot chocolate, and watched the cooks work with care and pride. the servers were nothing short of delightful.can't wait to go back.

5RhbQK7Jzuk09RhiQHlwLA.text: Very friendly and attentive staff. The crevice is not marinated so just sour and no flavor but otherwise everything was great! Lamb, beef heart skewers are very juicy and tender. Corn cake was just how I love it. Sweet and flavorful.

S6FaRTPsnW6FK1BTaAg4lg.text: Overall a yes, with a little hint of growing pains.My dining partner and I came in without a booking on a Sunday around 12:30. No booking? Sure, I guess we can sit at the bar. We were a bit close to the deep fryer (I like exposition kitchens), so it was a bit warm at first, but eventually I got used to the temperature and didn't notice it anymore. It is fun (though you feel a bit invasive almost) watching the cooks work, and I like feeling that the kitchen is a part of the dining experience. It is a lovely space in general, so no complaints there. We ordered: -Full Peruvian: Two fried eggs, confit pork chicharron, potato rosti, wild mushrooms, grilled tomato, avocado and toast-Omelet de Conchas y Setas: Scallop and wild mushroom omelette with sourdough toast-Cheeky Ceviche: Thinly sliced hake and cod cheeks in a Nikkei style tiger's milk with blood orange and spring onionThe Cheeky was awesome. I'd go back and just order that. Really, just a tasty dish. Tangy, great texture, unctuous fish cheeks... good stuff. The coffee was pretty good as well. Rob H.'s Full Peruvian looked and tasted pretty good. I was really envious of his avocado toast.  Mine was... blah. It was basically just a plain egg omelet (as in rolled egg) with a few mushrooms and baby scallops on top. With plain (though good quality) bread on the side. No colour, no butter, nothing on the toast at all... and its not like there was any sauce from the dish to mop up. Sure, those few scallop bites were sweet, but certainly not visually appealing nor worth the £9, considering all Rob got for his £10 with the Full Peruvian. It should have at least come with avocado toast like the other dish. I'm a fairly forgiving yelper, but I must say I was disappointed with my order.We had also ordered an order of the Yucas, but they never came, so we had to ask the waiter to take them off the bill, which he did promptly (but really, awkwardly and without apology... he tried to blame it on someone else or something, but really all you need to do is apologise). We were glad we didn't get them anyhow, because we were pretty full from everything else. In short, I will come back. And I hope to be writing a 5-star one next time based on how good that ceviche was.

hx6JcLKK_V4SzAYPLD9Rrg.text: Nothing like this restaurant for a fresh, classy brunch: love their smoothies and their gluten free granola are one of the freshest breakkie options in Shoreditch. Their pumpkin chicarrones are an awesome unique dessert and their kiwi quinoa burger is a guilt-free treat.

2xZyzT400FhBV0icpSlYcg.text: I wanted to give Andina 5 stars because when I walked in with a friend of mine when hunting for her birthday venues and the waitress was so friendly with a true 'can-do' attitude! Who wouldn't love it!But then the conversation with the manager began... I got the impression, she would be really unprofessional bitter lady. She told my friend off for not paying a deposit for uncompleted booking. Then mentioned paying a deposit several times (without mentioning how much the deposit is and what are the booking conditions). In her third email, she finally set a quote - we (as a group of 12) were required to have minimum spent £500. She wanted to force us into their set menu, which was even more expensive than having 3 courses from their standard menu. Using very unpleasant tone, never picking up the phone and never calling back. All the conversation was unnecessary spread into 3 days...Beware this lady in charge!

auqkKsJDvsJBWxyT7ElJNA.text: Amazing meal. It was so wonderful to experience some familiar ingredients through a new lens. We shared a few plates that were fantastic but that stand outs were the octopus and the ceviches. Can't wait to come back!!!

bPr8r9QZA2jzIYJj06cS8w.text: Loved the ceviche, although I don't think it's as tasty as its sister restaurant 'Ceviche' in Soho. Fun restaurant with great service. Thumbs up from me!

iwubZVVI0gHngwWbQxGwYA.text: Very inspiring Peruvian food. The pudin de maiz dish is one of the most wholesome breakfasts I've ever eaten. Will definitely return.

gX7KI_xCFKYEavMWlOsXIg.text: We came here for a lunch catch up with friends on their recommendation.  It was a good choice and we had a satisfying lunch. The restaurant describes itself as Peruvian tapas, so you should be ordering a number of dishes for the table and sharing. The overall experience has a 'Wahaca' feel to it. This really is an excellent way to catch up with friends and sample a variety of flavours and textures.They recommend three dishes per person, but we found that six dishes shared by three of us was plenty. My wife chose the Peruanazo full breakfast for herself as she was on a restricted diet. This had eggs, tacu-tacu with rice and butterbeans, belly bacon and saltado criollo (a kind of stir fry). She thought it was fine, but she didn't subsequently write home about it.The rest of us shared these dishes:Alas Sabogal: marinated fried chicken wingsSalmón en Panca: salmon marinated in panca chilli, spinach, sweet potato mashPulpo Chancón: grilled octopusLengua de Arguedas: slow cooked ox tongueOne of the ceviches, which came with a wasabi mashThe pulled pork burger (a little hard to share, but not so bad if you deconstruct it first)These were good dishes and my favourite was the ox tongue. I am a fan of how tender the meat was.

BSyMvFkAS99oq18u55OLbA.text: Wow - I have never tried ceviche before but after being taken by my friend who is Peruvian she tells me it's the best in London. Great service and friendly manager and we'll all the food was amazing - I tried all the spicy ceviche and pork belly and wow how the flavours lingered. Being a foodie this has been one of my best experiences! I also took my 1 year old son who they were really good with! I can't wait to go back! YOU MUST CHECK OUT THIS PLACE!!!

SgxhMfu__u2UWcs6KkAGjw.text: I've had peruvian before and it had none of the flavors like here (or lack thereof). Maybe it's different region? Not sure...but my opinion is that the food tries way too hard to look contemporary and cool for the east side, that it forgets about flavor. Went there for brunch and ordered the poached egg with fish. It came out and it was TINY. I was so hungry and I didn't order off the tapas menu and I was so shocked I accidentally said out loud, "That's it??" This dish was tiny...I should of taken the picture to scale. Even though it was tiny, the presentation was nice and looked nice, and that went downhill after I tasted it. The fish had bones and smelled and tasted too fishy for the plate's combination. Took over the whole dish. Maybe cod would be better b/c it's less fishy and more meaty. No flavor popped out. All I can smell and taste was fish and the texture was fish bones. Even a squirt of lime would of helped in this dish that was crying for something..anything. I don't know the name of the other dish we ordered but you can see from my pictures. It was like a traditional English breakfast with some bread and guacamole....lacked taste as well.I didn't think the menu was impressive nor the food. The interior and decor is really nice, but I feel they are trying too hard. There's no focus on the food and flavors. It's all name and show of being Peruvian w/o the Peruvian authenticity from the food.

NJ-FLVcIei7FCANl23u7Zg.text: The only reason I hesitated giving this place 5 stars is because the bill adds up very quickly and not every dish is perfect. But, the ones that are will blow you out of the water and make you feel less bad for spending £100... for five drinks, 6 sides/dishes and 2 desserts. We arrived at our reserved time, and our table wasn't ready. So, they sat us at a little shelf-like table I'll call a bar. We ordered a couple of pisco sours (£7.5 each), which were well presented and, if you like things that for some reason taste a bit like whiskey, you'll like these. But, if you were expecting something fruity like the descriptions seem to imply, you'll find the flavor is not quite like that. Either way, I drank my drink and noshed on some concha until our table was ready. Although service was friendly up until this point, we did get "checked" to see if we were truly on the reservation list while waiting at the bar--so sneaky folks, be advised, you need a reservation! The bar area is not for waiting without permission. We were soon moved downstairs, where it was super loud with talking and music, even more so than upstairs. But, we survived, yelling at each other across the table about how good the food was... From the Ceviche Classico to the Dulce con Cafe, we enjoyed [almost] every minute of our meal. The concha were good--nutty, corny, crunchy... a good way to start the meal (3.5 stars, £2). The ceviche classico was absolutely to die for--the PERFECT mix of lime and spice and flavors that played so well together (5 stars, £9). The ceviche andina on the other hand did not come in the awesomeness that is "tiger's milk", so it was rather bland and blah--not worth an additional £8 (2 stars). But, we ate it anyway. The quinoa croquetas were also quite amazing--4 little balls of cheesy quinoa goodness with a surprisingly amazing spicy/sweet sauce for smearing (5 stars, £3.5). The causa misti was a wonderfully fresh mix of veggies that complemented the rest of the dishes we'd eaten so far quite well (4.5 stars, £6). We were getting palatably satiated at this point from the wondrous flavors, but then remembered we hadn't yet gotten our grilled dishes.. I don't know if they intentionally took longer to space things out, but just an FYI--you might wait a bit for your "main" dish. First came the bistec escabechado. This is supposed to be a fancified version of lomo saltado. My co-eater absolutely loved it with full expressions on his face showing his glory. I, on the other hand, was not very impressed with it. Maybe after all the lime, this meat and potatoes (and peppers) dish was just a bit blah to me--and oversalted. I guess they soak the meat in the pisco, but clearly also plenty of salt. Unless you don't mind a lot of salt and very little spice, I'd say you can skip this dish without regret (2.5 stars, £13). Then came the salmon en panca. The salmon was the second most perfect I've ever eaten, with tons of flavor and just the right amount of seasoning, and it sat on a perfect little bed of spinach and had an interesting little smear of sweet potato to dress the plate (4.5 stars, £10). The only thing I would say, however, is that the salmon wasn't at all "exotic" to me, so although it was good, I'd say you don't have to try it... (Stick to the ceviche, etc. instead.)At this point, my pisco sour, glass of wine and his two piscos and a beer were adding up in terms of quantity and price with the wonderful meal we were having to the point that the server recommended maybe we just share one dessert. But, we shared two--the dulce con cafe and the 3-scoops of ice cream/sorbet. The dulce was fantastic--like a fancy pudding with so many different--but talentedly separate--flavors to tease your tongue despite the journey it had already been through (5 stars, £5.5). Can I just say how amazing it is that I could still taste that after all the lime and spice?! As for the ice cream/sorbet, I would say you can easily skip that. Our scoops included vanilla, cafe con leche and chili. Although they were all okay (2.5 stars, £5), they were not really worth it... Too watery, and the cafe con leche was too milky to the point of blandness, the vanilla though tasty was too watery (more sorbet than ice cream for these scoops), and the chili was just too much chili and not enough wow (need more cream and depth of flavor). Bottom line: The prices are high for tapas, especially if you find your brain converting the £ to the $. But, the food is quite amazing if you order the right dishes--so venture in for at least one or two tapas just to try it out--my rec ceviche classico, causa misti and dulce con cafe (and skip the pisco sour; it's not that special nor worth £7,5). And, then go get full elsewhere.

guIqOYkjzuyTWTqdI4NnbA.text: The food was nice but it was a bit of a slow service on Sat brunch ard 2pm. The area was lovely but a bit noisy downstairs. They have a music room good for abt 20pax for gatherings with a collection of LPs in wall mounted cabinets as display. The lady was kind enough to tour us and memtioned that u can play your own music in the music room.

_uWrMih2WNIjedn01v_pIw.text: Andina is the sister restaurant of the famous Peruvian restaurant Ceviche, which unsurprisingly comprises of a number of ceviche dishes. It also is a pisco bar, pisco being a grape-based spirit from South America. So there are pisco cocktails aplenty. The food is tapas-style, so they recommend 2-3 plates per person. 2 dishes were plenty for me and left me room to try their dessert. I found of all the dishes I tried (those I ordered myself and bits I tried from friends) I found that the only real difference between them was the texture. Every dish had a strong, overpowering flavour of lime to the point where it was the only real flavour of the food. Having never had ceviche before, this may purely be my problems with ceviche and not of the restaurant itself, especially seeing as the lime is what "cooks" the food.The cocktails were pretty good, with a few different options for pisco delivery. There is also a Peruvian beer for those who are curious, which is very malty. So for those who love their beers malty (I guess there are some?) then make sure you grab one of these.tl;dr: Sour, acidic food that can be a bit samey, but on the whole a decent meal and with alcohol choices that are a little bit different to what you can find elsewhere!

abbI1UucJuKaMROj7012LA.text: Delicious, delicious, delicious. Great food, really friendly and genuinely enthusiastic service and nice vibe. Had a REALLY great time seated at the bar downstairs last night. Apparently they recently changed their menu and revamped about 80% of it. I don't know what it was like before, but it sure is amazing now. Tried about six dishes and the standouts for me were definitely the pulpo chancón (grilled octopus) and the tiradito de atún (seared tuna ceviche). But everything was fantastic and the piscos are also a definite must.Would definitely recommend!

vGRGkDq4HEtKmei_UV9WpQ.text: Quinoa overload! Delicious, fresh and there's no possible way you could leave Andina without feeling full.I had the corn cake and urubamba smoothie which were both tasty with unusual flavours. Atmosphere was relaxed and staff were attentive and friendly. The only reason I didn't give Andina a 5 was because some of the flavours were overpowered by the quinoa (especially in the smoothie which was thick enough to be a meal).

mYLrd3wqA9IUjRY6rKiHHQ.text: Extremely good small bites brunch restaurant with a open kitchen, nice atmosphere and wide range of all non-regular dishes. Tastes are amazing but pricey. Especially if you're a big eater cause you need quite plates a few to be full

W6BbwNcObuNNAXhoIx2nTw.text: ummm maybe I am not a south american food fan but their food just does not suit my appetite.

gwpplDqaruU0cabh7vk0uA.text: This is a great place we stumbled upon by accident trying to get to another place around the way who had a line out the door, and am very glad at this happenstance. We walked in without reservations around 6:30 on a Sunday, and luckily were able to be accommodated at a sharing table in the back room. Service was very friendly and attentive, and the food was delicious. There were 5 of us, and so we ordered everything from the street food and grill sections of the menu, as well as thick chips, tuna ceviche and quinoa and avocado salad. Everything was quite good, I won't go into detail reviewing all but special mentions go to the Aubergine/Eggplant, Canard, Steak Fillet, Tuna Ceviche and Quinoa Avocado dishes.

0XnZLeD9CUNMo4u-9_lcdA.text: We went to Andina for dinner and it's really something new and the food is so fresh and tasty. The beef is a dream! The waitress was really nice and helpful. I will definitely come back.

u2-SbQsO3kggLKiBmUJlZw.text: Cute, fresh and bustling brunch spot. The food is super tasty, healthy and well presented. Come here as a weekend treat and find lots of options to suit any dietary needs. The staff are very accommodating and the food and drinks are lovingly made. But beware of ordering too much as everything sounds so tasty, just one item from the brunch tapas menu was enough for me. So take your time and enjoy it!
